title: Why was WW1 the only war to be almost exclusively fought in trenches? - Quora

response.answer_text: The fronts in Eastern Europe and the Near East were far more mobile than the Western Front, so I am not sure it can be said that the Great War was fought almost exclusively in trenches. But the Western Front was indeed almost exclusively fought as trench war. Why? The topic is a matter or a book (or two!) but if we had to simplify the issue, it would be because the technology of the era heavily favored defense over offense. The Great European Powers knew about trench warfare (they saw plenty in the Russo-Japanese War nine years earlier) and had furiously sought for alternatives. However, their proposal (among them armored cars) were seriously handicapped for how much weight their primitive internal combustion engines could carry with them. Machines guns were very heavy, their faster artillery was horse-mobile, and their heavier one was carried in trains and was impossible to dismount it and move it around in the mud quickly, and the infantry still had to arrive by foot (or taxi, as it happened in the Marne), but lacked trucks (or tracked APCs) to move them fast after a breach of the enemy line; and air-power was incipient, a matter for the ‘knights of the sky’ in their planes made of canvas stretched over wood frames, all that their primitive engines could propel. In an scenario where you have a heavily industrialized region, with armies struggling to move, and with heavy machine-guns and artillery mowing down anything that moved slow, and everything and everybody was moving slowly, it made sense to use trenches to cover your infantry. ::Why was WW1 the only war to be almost exclusively fought in trenches?::
